indicators.justification:
Estonia is required to make submissions to the EU and the UN following a common reporting format. The content of these reports is available as XLSX files from the Ministry of the Environment's international reporting page (1).

1) Ministry of the Environment - Climate International Reporting - Greenhouse gas emissions https://www.envir.ee/et/eesmargid-tegevused/kliima/rahvusvaheline-aruandlus/kui-palju-eestis-kasvuhoonegaase-tekib

evidence.title: Ministry of the Environment - Climate International Reporting - Greenhouse gas emissions

indicators.justification:
Estonia has published in 2008 the new red book for Estonia that includes information on endangered and at risk animals within the Estonian ecosystem (1). The data, while not originally available, has recently been put online and is available via Estonian biodiversity portal (2,3). 
1) Red book - https://old.envir.ee/sites/default/files/elfinder/article_files/eesti_punane_raamat_2008.pdf
2) Biodiversity portal - https://elurikkus.ee/
3) Estonian red book list - https://elurikkus.ee/lists/speciesListItem/list/drt101459479

indicators.justification:
There is a climate adaptation plan for Estonia through 2030 (1) that includes all relevant statistics and future challenges for the Estonian climate and ecosystem. However, the data behind this report does not appear to be available online.

indicators.justification:
Business registry data is well structured and available from the Estonian business registry (1) some data is free, but other data is available for purchase. Free data includes information such as the registry code of the company, creation date, address, share capital, tax debt information, etc… Paid data is related to submitted documents, annual reports, articles of association, and beneficial ownership. Outside of the business registry environment, it is also possible to download a copy of the freely available information in its entirety from the Estonian open government data portal (2).

1)	Estonian business registry - https://ariregister.rik.ee/index?lang=eng
2)	Estonian open government data portal – Estonian commercial register https://avaandmed.eesti.ee/datasets/ariregistri-avalikud-tasuta-andmed

evidence.title: Estonian Open Data Portal - Estonian Commercial Register
ACCESS DENIED? Availability and accessibility of beneficial ownership data in the European Union

indicators.justification:
Data and statistics emerging from the Estonian population register are available from TAI's statistics portal (1) as well as Statistics Estonia's database. This statistical database contains information on the Estonian population, trends, and other important statistical calculations.

1) Health Statistics and Health Research Database - https://statistika.tai.ee/index_en.html

2) Statistics Estonia's database (see Population -> Vital events) - https://andmed.stat.ee/en/stat

evidence.title: Health Statistics and Health Research Database

Birth information includes data about live-birth order and interval between last and previous live births to mother.
Birth information includes data about place of occurrence, place of usual residence of mother, and month of occurrence.
Birth information includes data about place of registration and month of registration.
Birth information includes data about age, educational attainment, and ethnic and/or national group of mother.
Birth information includes data about age of father and place of usual residence.
Birth information includes data about site of delivery, attendant at birth, and month in which prenatal care began.

indicators.justification:
Data at this level of granularity is not availble in Estonia to the public, but is known to governing officials. As open data, only aggregated data such as number of patients in hospitals, number of ICU places, number of patients on ventilators, etc... is available (1).

1) COVID-19 open data: https://www.terviseamet.ee/et/koroonaviirus/avaandmed

The data includes detailed information about the number and availability of medical devices or supplies, such as ventilators or oxygen cylinders.
The data includes detailed information about the number, type, and availability of COVID-19 tests.
The data includes detailed information about the number, type, and availability of COVID-19 vaccines.
Dataset is available free of charge.

indicators.justification:
All open data related to the Estonian COVID-19 pandemic and the response (e.g. vaccinations, hospitalizations, etc...) is available from TEHIK (Health and Welfare Information Systems Center) on the COVID-19 open data page (1). To help explore and visualize the data, TEHIK has used Tableau to create an interactive dashboard (2). 

1) COVID-19 open data: https://www.terviseamet.ee/et/koroonaviirus/avaandmed
2) COVID-19 Data Visualization and Statisics: https://www.terviseamet.ee/et/koroonaviirus/koroonakaart

indicators.justification:
The legal act describing land ownership and land data is the Law of Property act (1). Data can be queried from the online land register (2), most data is available for a fee and only to authenticated (must have Estonian e-ID) and signed in (using e-ID) users. Price related statistics for real estate are available to the public only in an aggregated format once five or more sales within a specific category have been conducted (3). 

1) Law of Property Act - https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/ee/501072015002/consolide/current
2) e-Land Register - https://kinnistusraamat.rik.ee/Avaleht.aspx
3) Real estate price statistics - https://www.maaamet.ee/kinnisvara/htraru/

indicators.justification:
The Ministry of Finance is responsible for the budget management of Estonia. The main place to access data related to the annual budget is the application "riigiraha" (1). Additionally, the State Shared Service Center assists with accounting. Data from this service can be viewed using the SALDO app (2). 

1) Riigiraha: https://riigiraha.fin.ee/QvAJAXZfc/opendoc.htm?document=riigiraha.qvw&lang=en-US&host=local&anonymous=true/
2) SALDO: https://saldo.rtk.ee/saldo-app/

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

2) Attached as file

indicators.justification:

indicators.justification:
The Estonian public procurement registry maintains an open data page (1,2) that allows for all procurement related information to be downloaded directly or via an API. The data and information contained is well documented and in line with EU e-Procurement standards.

1) Estonian National Procurement Portal Open Data: https://riigihanked.riik.ee/rhr-web/#/open-data
2) Estonian Open Data Portal - Public Procurement register: https://avaandmed.eesti.ee/datasets/riigihangete-register

evidence.title: Estonian National Procurement Portal Open Data
Estonian Open Data Portal - Public Procurement Register Data

indicators.justification:
The main work covering the development of Estonia's open government data ecosystem is the open government data action plan (1). Within this document there are specific goals related to increasing the usage of open government data in Estonia. Additionally, the Estonian government has rebuilt the open data portal (2), and within this portal there is the ability for anyone to request data that is missing and submit user created applications based on open government data. 
1)	Open government data action plan -  https://digiriik.ee/index.php/avaandmete-tegevuskava/
2)	Estonian open government data portal - https://avaandmed.eesti.ee/

indicators.justification:
The Estonian government has developed an open government data action plan (1) and redeveloped a new open data portal (2). Open government data has been made a political priority, and in the past 3 years large and rapid developments have been made (3).

1) Estonian open government data action plan: https://digiriik.ee/index.php/avaandmete-tegevuskava/
2) Estonian open government data portal: https://avaandmed.eesti.ee
3) McBride, K., Olesk, M., Kütt, A., & Shysh, D. (2020). Systemic change, open data ecosystem performance improvements, and empirical insights from Estonia: A country-level action research study. Information Polity, 25(3), 377-402.

evidence.title: Systemic change, open data ecosystem performance improvements, and empirical insights from Estonia: A country-level action research study

responses.response_text: The open data initiative covers much of the national government, and there are similar initiatives in many sub-national areas.

indicators.justification:
Due to the digital nature of Estonia's government, most local municipal governments have some experience with data management. At a minimum, such governments maintain document registries which are available to citizens publicly. Furthermore, municipal governments of cities such as Tallinn and Tartu both have their own open government data initiatives (1,2) and the state is coordinating and developing local data management capacities even further (3)
1)	Tallinn open data portal - https://avaandmed.tallinn.ee/
2)	Tartu open data portal - https://tartu.ee/et/avaandmed
3)	Local government data management training - https://kovandmehaldus.publicon.ee/et/paevakava/

There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place to provide a comprehensive framework for data sharing.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place for consistent data management and publication.
There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

responses.response_text: The examples given represent common practice: many cities or regions have comparable capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
Estonia is increasingly providing access to trainings for data management, data literacy, and data skills. Such trainings are included within the open government data action plan (1), as part of the government's AI (Kratt) initiative (2), and also general trainings under the state shared service center (3), which also address the training-related goals of the open government data action plan.
 
1)	Open government data action plan - https://digiriik.ee/index.php/avaandmete-tegevuskava/
2)	Kratid trainings - https://www.kratid.ee/koolitused
3)	State shared service center trainings https://rtk.ee/finantsarvestus-ja-personaliteenus/personaliarendus/koolitus-ja-arendustegevused

indicators.justification:
Due to Estonia's developed digital government, most datasets and registries are interoperable through the usage of Estonia's x-road platform (1). At the personal level, data is often interlinked via the "isikukood" (personal identity code). At the business level data can be further linked through the unique identifiers provided in the business registry (2). Services such as www.teatmik.ee (3) or www.opener.ee (4) well represent the interconnectivity of such datasets. 
1) Data exchange layer x-road: https://www.ria.ee/en/state-information-system/x-tee.html
2) Estonian business registry: https://ariregister.rik.ee/
3) Teatmik - https://www.teatmik.ee/
4) Opener - https://opener.ee/

responses.response_text: The datasets of this theme consistently use common identifiers and share common identifiers with relevant datasets in other themes.

The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
Data sharing between public agencies takes place via the interoperability platform x-road. Such data sharing is regulated by the public information act (1) and the information system data exchange layer regulation (2). Additionally, most individual databases (for example, the population register) will have further requirements dictating how data can be shared and with whom. 
1)	Public information act – https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/529032019012/consolide
2)	Information system data exchange layer regulation - https://www.riigiteataja.ee/akt/127092016004?leiaKehtiv

indicators.justification:
In Estonia, personal data protection is regulated by the personal data protection act (1). The personal data protection act includes an implementing provision for the EU's GDPR, outlines what data must be public by default, implements a process for obtaining information from public authorities, and, therefore, serves as the legal foundation for data related issues in Estonia. 

1) Personal data protection act -https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/523012019001/consolide

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?

The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders.
The framework provides rights of redress
The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.
The framework addresses algorithmic decision making.
Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response.

indicators.justification:
Inside Estonia, open government data is regulated and driven by a mix of strategies and regulations. First, there is the Public Information Act (1) that discusses open and public data. Second, there is the "Green Book" on open government data that outlines goals and best practices related to open data inside Estonia (2). Finally, there is the open data action plan (2020-2022) (3)

1) Public information act - https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/529032019012/consolide

2) Green book on open government data - https://www.mkm.ee/sites/default/files/avaliku-teabe-masinloetava-avalikustamise-roheline-raamat-20141125_0.odt 

3) Estonian open government data action plan - https://digiriik.ee/index.php/avaandmete-tegevuskava/

indicators.justification:
There are a number of regulations handling the management, structure, and publication of public sector accounting and finance data. These are the state budget act (1) the public information act (2) the budget classification regulation (3) the public sector financial accounting and report guidelines (4) and the accounting act (5). Between these five there is clear requirements for how budget information should be structured, collected, and released publicly. 

1) state budget act: https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/ee/511072016011/consolide/current
2) public information act: https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/ee/514112013001/consolide/current
3) budget classification regulation - https://www.riigiteataja.ee/akt/116122016016?leiaKehtiv
4) public sector financial accounting and report guidelines – https://www.riigiteataja.ee/akt/128102016012?leiaKehtiv 
5) accounting act - https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/ee/514052021001/consolide/current

indicators.justification:
There are two main sources related to the public consultation process in Estonia, the rules for good legislative practice (1) and legislative drafting and the best practices for public engagement (2). Changes to regulations and proposed legislation likely to have a strong impact on the public must be made available for public consultation via the Estonian policy draft information system (3). Comments collected here are available for all to see, and the government must respond to such comments. 

1) Rules for good legislative practice and legislative drafting - https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/508012015003/consolide
2) Best practices for public engagement - https://www.riigikantselei.ee/kaasamise-hea-tava
3) Policy draft information system - https://eelnoud.valitsus.ee/main

responses.response_text: No evidence of actors or entities using this data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?

indicators.justification:
The media is one of the largest users of political integrity data in Estonia, they often use publicly available data to investigate and hold politicians accountable in case of wrong doing. Civil society similarly has begun to engage more heavily with such data to development applications (1, 2) that can be used to drive integrity of the political system

1) Opener application - www.opener.ee
2) Visualization of political party financing https://rahapada.salk.ee

responses.response_text: There are widespread and regular cases of actors or entities using this kind of open data for accountability purposes.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
There is limited usage of open procurement data in applications, visualizations, dashboards, or other services within Estonia. The only clear example is opener.ee (1), which is led by a civil society organization with support from the Ministry of Finance.

1) opener.ee https://opener.ee/

responses.response_text: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
